title: Can I file bankruptcy on a default judgment ( civil) I just received notice that my motion to set aside was denied
question: I was not served properly I was out of state working and a summons came to my mothers house where I was not living at that time yet that was the only place that it could be received the person who summons said my mother recieved it and they had asked her name and who she was with full name .. My mother was not home her husband had passed away that morning and my mom was not at home there was family members but they nobody told me anything but it also stated that my mother recieved it at she never did my moms name was wrong also.. I also went to self help center they said i had up to 2 years to set aside judgment it's Been 7 months and they denied my motion to set aside because its after 6 months.. Wondering if I can file bankruptcy or is there something else I should do
answers: Bankruptcy is an extreme decision. For what amount is the judgment? If it is a significant amount, you should hire an attorney to refile the motion. This could cost less than a bankruptcy.

Bankruptcy may be an option. I suggest you consult local bankruptcy counsel. The information you received from the self-help center was incorrect. The maximum period of time to move to set-aside a default or default judgment is "reasonable" time as determined by the judge who heard your case. Six months is the outside limit when the motion is based upon mistake, surprise, inadvertence, or excusable neglect.

If your debts are unmanageable, it would benefit you to confer with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney to review your financial situation, because most judgments are dischargeable, if you qualify to file.
For example, if an unsecured creditor obtains a judgment, it generally does not provide the creditor any better claim in bankruptcy, so you can stop collections whenever you file.

You could appeal the ruling denying 473 relief but doesn't sound like you have appealable issues of law. Or motion for reconsideration depending on grounds. (And also whether there is statement of decision or hearing transcript to determine basis for ruling and evidence)

Also not clear $ amount if judgement and not clear if judgement is collectible? Assets? Age? Etc.

If amount is significant and have assets immediately seek consultation of bankruptcy attorney to see if you qualify to file for 7 and appeal attorney to get opinion on grounds or appeal if any.

If judgment falls within certain un dischargeable debts (fraud, DUI , family support,etc) you will have challenges.

Even if no assets still should seek bankruptcy attorney to review your case (future earnings, inheritance , awards or judgements ) to best advise you.

Good luck.
Unless the judgment is related to fraud, yes, it should be dischargable in bankruptcy. However, consult with an attorney who specializes in bankruptcy to confirm.
